Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical description:
Lasers and other light sources will be used to measure the properties of negative ions, which are atoms and molecules that have an extra electron. High-precision measurements of how tightly the extra electron is bound will be useful for modeling chemical reactions and plasma interactions for such practical applications as the manufacturing of semiconductors for computers and other electronic devices. The detailed studies of negative ions will yield insights into "dynamical many-body interactions" which are central to understanding how collections of particles behave differently from what one would expect from the knowledge gained by studying single particles in isolation. These interactions are general phenomenon of interest for a broad range of fields in physics, chemistry, and materials science, including nanotechnology. The project will enhance the research and teaching infrastructure of Denison University, an undergraduate college. Students will participate in the experiments both on-campus and at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, providing important research experiences for young scientists including technical training in electronics, computers, lasers, and optics.

Technical description:
This project studies the interactions of photons with negative ions in two related series of experiments. The extra electron in a negative ion is bound predominantly by electron correlation effects and therefore negative ions provide a fertile testing ground for state-of-the-art atomic physics calculations regarding these multi-body interactions. In the first series of experiments, complex atomic negative ions are investigated on-campus at Denison University using tunable infrared laser light to detach outer-shell electrons. The ground and upper state photodetachment thresholds of several lanthanide and Group III negative ions (gallium and possibly thallium) will be measured in order to determine the electron affinities and energy levels. There is currently strong disagreement between theoretical predictions and experimental photoelectron spectroscopy results for these systems. The faculty and student researchers will also investigate resonances and bound excited states in lanthanide ions including bound-bound electric-dipole transitions that exist in the negative ions of cerium and lanthanum. The second series of complementary experiments will investigate inner-shell photodetachment from the negative ions of oxygen, hydrogen, and carbon chains of n numbers of carbon atoms (O-, H-, C_n-) and other atomic and molecular species using high energy (12-1000 eV) photons at the Advanced Light Source synchrotron. These experiments continue the PIs' investigations into the effects of the outer-shell electrons on the detaching inner electron's wavefunction. The dynamic multi-electron interactions in the photoexcitation of the highly correlated cores of negative ions continue to challenge the fundamental understanding of atomic structure. Investigations into heavy negative ions and detection of the neutral decay products will test the latest theories describing inner-shell photodetachment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Negative ions are atoms or molecules with an extra electron attached. Atomic negative ions are of both fundamental and applied interest since they are found in a wide variety of physical situations including terrestrial and stellar atmospheres and electrical discharges and plasmas. The extra electron in a negative ion is bound predominantly by electron correlation effects and therefore negative ions provide a fertile testing ground for state-of-the-art atomic physics calculations regarding these multi-body interactions. These correlation effects are one of the fundamental mysteries of quantum mechanics. During our three-year project we studied the interactions of photons with negative ions in two series of experiments. A crossed ion beam/tunable laser system was used to measure high precision photodetachment cross sections near the ground state thresholds of several lanthanide and Group III negative ions for the first time. Complementary experiments on inner-shell detachment were performed at the Advanced Light Source (ALS) synchrotron user facility at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.  

The Intellectual Merit of this work included both the development of new knowledge and refinement/correction of existing information on negative ions. The lanthanides are interesting because they have partially-filled outer electron shells and exhibit enhanced electron correlation effects. The ground state photodetachment threshold of La- was studied to determine the electron affinity, the initial states of the outer electrons and to search for resonances like those we have discovered in La- and Ce-. Photodetachment spectra for Ga- and Tl- have been measured and are being analyzed. The previous disagreement between theoretical predictions and experimental photoelectron spectroscopy results for these systems has been largely resolved. The researchers also investigated bound excited states in La- including bound-bound electric-dipole transitions that exist only in La- and one or two other negative ions. The series of inner-shell experiments investigated photodetachment from Ni-, O-, Cn- (carbon chains) and other atomic and molecular negative ions using high energy (12 – 1000 eV) photons at the ALS. These experiments continued a series of studies by the PIs to investigate the effects of the outer-shell electrons on the detaching inner electron’s wavefunction. The dynamic multi-electron interactions in the photoexcitation of the highly correlated negative ion cores continue to challenge the fundamental understanding of atomic structure. Investigations into heavy negative ions help test the latest theories describing inner-shell photodetachment. One refereed journal article and numerous conference presentations resulted from this period. 

The Broader Impacts of this proposal included important contributions to other areas of physics and significant amounts of education and research training. The bound-bound electric-dipole (E1) transitions in La- are excellent candidates for laser cooling of negative ions which will aid efforts to sympathetically cooling anti-protons. The program provided research opportunities for two Investigators and from two to four undergraduate student researchers per summer. These projects provided important research experiences for young scientists. The Co-PIs worked closely in the laboratory with students at Denison and also travelled with the undergraduates to the ALS for experimental runs at the state-of-the-art user facility. In addition to providing significant hands-on experimental research training opportunities, this continuing experimental program contributed positively to the overall research atmosphere on campus and to classroom activities in our Quarks to Cosmos, Modern Physics, Optics and Quantum Mechanics courses. Ten ~10 week-long summer projects for undergraduate students were supported during this award. Both Co-Investigators and many of our undergraduate students were also heavily involved with student-faculty collaborative public science outreach projects that presented Physics and Astronomy programs to hundreds of people each year.
